title: Is English really English?
intro: Many of the English words we use today like beer, hand, mother and love have all survived from Old English. Neil and Georgina discuss where the English language we use today really comes from.
this_week_question: The year 1066 is remembered for a famous battle when the French-speaking Norman king, William the Conqueror, invaded England – but what is the name of the famous battle? Is it...
Listen to the programme to find out the answer.

vocab.desc: when an army of country uses force to enter and take control of another country
letter or group of letters added to the end of a word to make a new word
using the words that most people use in ordinary conversation
the basic parts that are put together to make something
from someone else’s point of view; how someone else would experience something
used to say what something is really like

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Hello. This is 6 Minute English from BBC Learning English. I’m Neil.

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: And I’m Georgina.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Gōdne mergen! Mé lícap pé tó métanne!

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: I beg your pardon, Neil? Is something stuck in your throat?! Are you speaking a foreign language?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Ha! Well, actually Georgina, I was saying, ‘Good morning, pleased to meet you’ in English - but not the English you and I speak. That was Anglo-Saxon, or Old English, the earliest form of English, spoken in the Middle Ages – so, between the 5th and 15th century.

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: It doesn’t sound anything like the way people talk nowadays.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: No, but it’s surprising how many of the words we use today have survived from Old English – beer, wine, drink, fish, bread, butter, eye, ear, mouth, head, hand, foot, life, love, laughter, mother, daughter, sister, brother, son, father – all Anglo-Saxon words!

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: Wow, so many everyday words! But what about the classics - Latin and Greek? I thought a lot of English vocabulary came from there.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: That’s also true, but the history of English is the history of invasions – you know, when the army of one country fights to enter and control another country.

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: Like the Roman invasion of Britain?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Right, and later invasions too, by Norse-speaking Vikings and Germanic Saxons. In fact, Georgina, that reminds me of my quiz question.

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: Go on then, but in modern English if you don’t mind…

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: OK. Well, the year 1066 is remembered for a famous battle when the French-speaking Norman king, William the Conqueror, invaded England – but what is the name of the famous battle? Is it:

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: Hmm, my history’s not great, Neil, but I think it’s, b) The Battle of Hastings.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: OK, Georgina, we’ll find out ‘later’ - another Old English word there! But it’s not just words that survive from Anglo-Saxon, it’s word endings too – the suffix , or letters added to the end of a word to modify its meaning.

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: Right, like adding ‘s’ to make something plural, as in: one bird, two birds. Or the ‘ness’ in ‘goodness’ and ‘happiness’. And ‘dom’, as in, ‘freedom’ and kingdom’.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Poet Michael Rosen is fascinated by Old English. Here he is talking about word suffixes to Oxford University professor Andy Orchard for BBC Radio 4’s programme, Word of Mouth.

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: Listen out for the proportion of modern English that comes from Anglo-Saxon.

transcript.author: Michael Rosen
transcript.text: ‘I walked’ – that ‘walked’ the ‘et’ bit on the end.

transcript.author: Professor Andy Orchard
transcript.text: Yeah, the ‘ed’ ending. Most modern verbs – if we were to say, ‘I texted my daughter’, I mean text obviously comes from Latin… ‘I tweeted’ – we still lapse to the Anglo-Saxon.

transcript.author: Michael Rosen
transcript.text: And, generally when I’m speaking, just let’s do it in mathematical terms, what proportion can we say is Old English? Can we say, like, about 80% in common parlance , sorry to use a French word there?

transcript.author: Professor Andy Orchard
transcript.text: In speech it would be something like that – in the written language, less. They’re the basic building blocks of who we are and what we think.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Professor Orchard estimates that 80 percent of spoken English in common parlance comes from Anglo-Saxon. In common parlance means the words and vocabulary that most people use in ordinary, everyday conversation.

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: So Anglo-Saxon words are the building blocks of English - the basic parts that are put together to make something.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: He also thinks that the languages we speak shape the way we see the world.

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: Here’s Michael Rosen and Professor Andy Orchard discussing this idea on BBC Radio 4 programme, Word of Mouth:

transcript.author: Michael Rosen
transcript.text: Can we say that English speakers today, as I’m speaking to you now, view the world through Anglo-Saxon eyes , through Anglo-Saxon words? Can we say that?

transcript.author: Professor Andy Orchard
transcript.text: Well, in Old English poetry it’s always raining and I suppose it’s always raining today. There is a retrospective element, that we’re still inhabiting that worldview, those ideas; the same words, the same simple ideas that they inhabited. And what’s extraordinary if you think about the history of English is despite the invasions by the Norse and by the Norman, and then despite the years of empire when we’re bringing things back, the English that we’re speaking today is still at its root Old English word, at its heart Old English word, still very much English.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Michael Rosen asks if English speakers see the world through Anglo-Saxon eyes . When we see something through someone’s eyes , we see it from their perspective, their point of view.

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: And Professor Orchard replies by saying that despite all the history of invasion and empire, the English we speak today is still Old English at heart – a phrase used to say what something is really like.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Wow! So much history crammed into six minutes! And now, time for one more history fact.

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: Do you mean your quiz question, Neil? What’s the name of the famous battle of 1066?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: What did you say, Georgina?

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: I said b) The Battle of Hastings.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Which was… the correct answer! The Battle of Hastings in 1066 played a big part in the Norman Conquest and mixing French words into the language.

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: And I also know how the English ruler, King Harold, died – shot through the eye with an arrow!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Ouch! OK, let’s recap the vocabulary, some of which exists because of invasions – when one country enters and controls another.

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: A suffix is added to the end of a word to make a new word.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: The phrase in common parlance means using ordinary, everyday words.

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: Building blocks are the basic parts used to make something.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: To see things through someone’s eyes means, from their point of view.

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: And finally, at heart is used to say what something is really like.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: That’s all for this programme. Join us again soon at 6 Minute English but for now, ‘far gesund!’ – that’s Old English for ‘goodbye’!

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: Far gesund!
